message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Communication and Control in Collaborative UAVs: Recent Advances and Future Trends
Paper Abstract: The recent progress in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) technology has significantly advanced UAV-based applications for military, civil, and commercial domains. Nevertheless, the challenges of establishing high-speed communication links, flexible control strategies, and developing efficient collaborative decision-making algorithms for a swarm of UAVs limit their autonomy, robustness, and reliability. Thus, a growing focus has been witnessed on collaborative communication to allow a swarm of UAVs to coordinate and communicate autonomously for the cooperative completion of tasks in a short time with improved efficiency and reliability. This work presents a comprehensive review of collaborative communication in a multi-UAV system. We thoroughly discuss the characteristics of intelligent UAVs and their communication and control requirements for autonomous collaboration and coordination. Moreover, we review various UAV collaboration tasks, summarize the applications of UAV swarm networks for dense urban environments and present the use case scenarios to highlight the current developments of UAV-based applications in various domains. Finally, we identify several exciting future research direction that needs attention for advancing the research in collaborative UAVs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, "autonomous systems" is a broad term that refers to different concepts depending on context:

## Key Types of Autonomous Systems

**Internet/Networking Context:**
An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

**Mathematics Context:**
In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

**Robotics and AI Context:**
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

**Research and Development:**
The aim of the program is academic basic research in artificial intelligence, autonomous systems, and software. This reflects how autonomous systems research spans multiple disciplines including control theory, robotics, and AI.

The term encompasses systems that can operate independently, make decisions, and adapt to their environments without constant external control.

Based on the search results, "autonomous systems" is a broad term that refers to different concepts depending on context:

## Key Types of Autonomous Systems

**Internet/Networking Context:**
An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operators on behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

**Mathematics Context:**
In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

**Robotics and AI Context:**
An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

**Research and Development:**
The aim of the program is academic basic research in artificial intelligence, autonomous systems, and software. This reflects how autonomous systems research spans multiple disciplines including control theory, robotics, and AI.

The term encompasses systems that can operate independently, make decisions, and adapt to their environments without constant external control.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent systems"

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_(multi-agent_systems_development_platform)"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multi-agent systems:

## Definition and Core Concept

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with no agent designated as controlling (or the system is effectively reduced to a monolithic system).(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organization as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## What Can Compose a MAS

Multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, but agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Intelligence Methods

Intelligence may include methodic, functional, procedural approaches, algorithmic search or reinforcement learning. Additionally, with advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about unmanned aerial vehicles:

## Definition and Basics

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Consumer Market Development

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, crop spraying, and disaster monitoring.

I've completed a web search for "Robot coordination." Here's what I found:

## Key Findings on Robot Coordination

**Human-Robot Collaboration:**
Collaboration is defined as a special type of coordinated activity, one in which two or more agents work jointly with each other, together performing a task or carrying out the activities needed to satisfy a shared goal.(no content)Industrial applications of human-robot collaboration involve Collaborative Robots, or cobots, that physically interact with humans in a shared workspace to complete tasks such as collaborative manipulation or object handovers.

**Multi-Robot Coordination:**
The focus in multi-robot team work is on developing simple generic mechanisms that result in coordinated group behavior, either implicitly or explicitly.

**Motor Coordination:**
Coordinating numerous robot joints for even simple matters, like negotiating stairs, is difficult.(no content)Target robotic cognitive capabilities include perception processing, attention allocation, anticipation, planning, complex motor coordination, reasoning about other agents and perhaps even about their own mental states.

**Social and Developmental Coordination:**
In developmental robotics, social and linguistic skills include the acquisition of simple social behavioural games such as turn-taking, coordinated interaction, lexicons, syntax and grammar, and the grounding of these linguistic skills into sensorimotor skills.

Robot coordination spans multiple domains, from mechanical joint control to multi-agent systems and human-robot interaction.

Web search results for query: "Control theory"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

## Control Theory

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

### How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable and compares it with the reference or set point. The difference between actual and desired value, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### History

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

### Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Wireless network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_network"},{"title":"Wireless - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless"},{"title":"List of wireless network protocols - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wireless_network_protocols"},{"title":"Wireless LAN - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_LAN"},{"title":"List of wireless network technologies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wireless_network_technologies"},{"title":"Wi-Fi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi"},{"title":"Category:Wireless communication systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Wireless_communication_systems"},{"title":"Wired communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wired_communication"},{"title":"Multicast - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multicast"},{"title":"Optical wireless communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_wireless_communications"}]

## Wireless Communication Networks

Here's an overview of wireless communication networks based on the search results:

### Definition and Basics

A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.(no content)Wireless networking allows homes, telecommunications networks, and business installations to avoid the costly process of introducing cables into a building, or as a connection between various equipment locations.

### Types of Wireless Networks

Examples of wireless networks include cell phone networks, wireless local area networks (WLANs), wireless sensor networks, satellite communication networks, and terrestrial microwave networks.

Some key types include:

- **Cellular Networks**: A cellular network or mobile network is a radio network distributed over land areas called cells, each served by at least one fixed-location transceiver, known as a cell site or base station. In a cellular network, each cell characteristically uses a different set of radio frequencies from all their immediate neighbouring cells to avoid any interference. When joined these cells provide radio coverage over a wide geographic area.

- **Wireless LANs (WLANs)**: A wireless LAN (WLAN) is a wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network (LAN) within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, campus, or office building.

- **Wireless Personal Area Networks (WPANs)**: Wireless personal area networks (WPANs) connect devices within a relatively small area, that is generally within a person's reach.

### Generations of Cellular Networks

1G refers to the first generation of cellular network technology. These analog telecommunication standards were introduced in 1979 and used until replaced by 2G digital systems. The main distinction was that 1G transmitted voice as analog radio signals, while 2G transmitted all communications digitally.(no content)4G provided broadband Internet access for mobile devices, supporting IP telephony, high-definition video, and real-time communication. LTE and WiMAX were the first 4G implementations.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- **Wireless LANs (WLANs)**: A wireless LAN (WLAN) is a wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network (LAN) within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, campus, or office building.

- **Wireless Personal Area Networks (WPANs)**: Wireless personal area networks (WPANs) connect devices within a relatively small area, that is generally within a person's reach.

### Generations of Cellular Networks

1G refers to the first generation of cellular network technology. These analog telecommunication standards were introduced in 1979 and used until replaced by 2G digital systems. The main distinction was that 1G transmitted voice as analog radio signals, while 2G transmitted all communications digitally.(no content)4G provided broadband Internet access for mobile devices, supporting IP telephony, high-definition video, and real-time communication. LTE and WiMAX were the first 4G implementations.

## Swarm Robotics

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about swarm robotics:

### Definition and Core Concept

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, unlike distributed robotic systems in general.(no content)Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.

### Key Characteristics

Swarm robotics systems are built on several fundamental principles:

- Robots are autonomous.
- Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems, like radio frequency or infrared.
- Robots do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge.
- Robots cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.(no content)Miniaturization is also key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the effect of the swarm-intelligent approach to achieve meaningful behavior at swarm-level through a greater number of interactions on an individual level.

### Inspiration from Nature

Swarm robotics takes inspiration from nature (e.g. collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature such as honey bee aggregation).(no content)Swarm intelligence systems consist typically of a population of simple agents or boids interacting locally with one another and with their environment. The inspiration often comes from nature, especially biological systems.

### History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.

### Applications

Swarm robotics has diverse potential applications:

- A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions. Swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely, to explore the unknown environment and solve complex mazes via onboard sensors.
- Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in the field of manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing. This is particularly useful for the production of large structures and components, where traditional 3D printing is not able to be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

I've completed a web search for "Decision making algorithm" and found several relevant results. Here's what I discovered:

## Overview

Automated decision-making (ADM) is the use of data, machines and algorithms to make decisions in a range of contexts, including public administration, business, health, education, law, employment, transport, media and entertainment, with varying degrees of human oversight or intervention.

## Key Types of Decision-Making Algorithms

**Decision Trees**: Decision trees are among the most popular machine learning algorithms given their intelligibility and simplicity because they produce algorithms that are easy to interpret and visualize, even for users without a statistical background.

**Sequential Decision Making**: Sequential decision making is a concept in control theory and operations research, which involves making a series of decisions over time to optimize an objective function, such as maximizing cumulative rewards or minimizing costs. This process is commonly addressed using methods like Markov decision processes (MDPs) and dynamic programming.

**Heuristic Approaches**: A heuristic or heuristic technique is any approach to problem solving that employs a pragmatic method that is not fully optimized, perfected, or rationalized, but is nevertheless "good enough" as an approximation or attribute substitution. Where finding an optimal solution is impossible or impractical, heuristic methods can be used to speed up the process of finding a satisfactory solution.

## Technologies Involved

ADM may involve large-scale data from a range of sources, such as databases, text, social media, sensors, images or speech, that is processed using various technologies including computer software, algorithms, machine learning, natural language processing, artificial intelligence, augmented intelligence and robotics.
